clinical_study.official_title: Consequences, Costs and Cost-effectiveness of Different Workforce Configurations in English Acute Hospitals: a Longitudinal Retrospective Study Using Routinely Collected Data

brief_summary.textblock:
Background: The NHS is facing significant challenges in recruiting and retaining staff, particularly registered nurses (RNs). Recruiting unregistered staff is often adopted as a solution to the RN shortage; however recent research found a negative effect of low RN staffing levels on mortality with no evidence that high levels of assistant staff could mitigate the increased risk. Economic modelling suggested that increases in skill mix were potentially cost-effective, but these findings derive from a single NHS hospital Trust with limited cost and outcome data.
Aims and objectives: This project aims to estimate the consequences, costs and cost effectiveness of variation in the size and composition of the staff on hospital wards in England. In order to provide estimates that are more likely to apply across the NHS, this study will include at least four hospitals and consider a wider range of outcomes and sources of costs, including death within 30 days of admission, adverse events such as infections, length of hospital stay, readmissions and rates of staff sickness.
Methods: This retrospective longitudinal observational study will use routinely collected data on ward and shift level nurse staffing, and patient outcomes. Data will be derived from the E-Roster systems, used by hospitals to record all planned and worked shifts. The investigators will consider all rostered direct care staff. These data will be linked to patient data derived from the hospital patient administration system (PAS); and other clinical systems and databases of adverse events (e.g. datix). Relationships between RN and assistant staffing levels and outcomes will be explored using survival models incorporating mixed effects. The investigators will use the results of these analyses to model the costs and consequences of different staffing configurations and to estimate the incremental cost-effectiveness associated with change. Our study will provide evidence to inform staffing levels and skill mix planning in the NHS, highlighting potential cost savings, and offering improved patient safety and reduced adverse staff outcomes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 1: Number of safety events according to NHS Improvement "Safety Thermometer" data (falls, pressure ulcers, venous thromboembolism, urinary catheters & UTIs).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed daily during each patient hospital admission. Data are in the form of monthly aggregates. We will use a period of at least 2 years (2017-2018)

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 1: Rating of nurse-specific and global patient experience according to NHS Adult Inpatient Survey (Questions 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 68).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed on discharge from hospital for each patient admission. Data are in the form of monthly aggregates. We will use a period of at least 2 years (2017-2018).

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 2: Length of hospital stay for each patient.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patient admissions and discharges assessed each day within study period (March 2015- March 2019). We will consider patients whose whole stay was within the study period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 2: Readmission within 30 days of discharge
Study 2: Incidence of other adverse patient outcomes e.g. pressure ulcers, hospital acquired infection, falls.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed daily until patient's discharge from hospital and within study period (March 2015- March 2019).

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 2: Incidences of staff sickness absence.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed each shift (2-3 times per day) within study period (March 2015- March 2019).

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 2: Aggregated staff costs (salaries/wages) according to staff rosters.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Yearly aggregates within study period (March 2015- March 2019).

secondary_outcome.measure: Study 2: Other service costs associated with adverse outcomes e.g. readmission.
Study 2: Incremental cost per life saved and per quality-adjusted life year.

intervention.description: Study 1: Variation in staffing levels at Trust level (between Trusts). Study 2: Variation in nurse staffing/ skill mix on wards within Trusts

criteria.textblock:
Study 1
Inclusion Criteria:
- acute hospital Trust in England
- data available in national datasets (as specified in protocol) for Trust level staffing, bed occupancy and outcomes
Exclusion Criteria:
-
Study 2
Inclusion Criteria:
- acute hospital Trust in England
- willingness and ability to provide anonymised patient data and the ability to provide electronic roster data for a minimum period of 1 year prior to the commencement of the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
-
